title: BlueScope CEO calls out China's huge steel export volumes | The Business | ABC NEWS
description: Leading Australian steelmaker BlueScope says it is satisfied with the federal government's recent moves to impose anti-dumping duties against some Chinese exporters of steel products, while acknowledging the playing field is still far from level.  The company's new chief executive, Tania Archibald says BlueScope is dealing with the third straight year of bottom of cycle spreads. "I think it's really driven by the property market in China", she says. "The relatively lower levels of demand that we're seeing in China at the moment, that will eventually recover. But how it's manifesting of course is these large volumes of steel exports that are coming out of China, they're having a dampening effect on margins and prices."  Tania Archibald confirmed BlueScope remains interested in the Whyalla Steelworks' potential for DRI or direct reduced iron technology to produce "green iron". BlueScope leads an international consortium investigating the future viability of a DRI project at Whyalla.  BlueScope released its half-year earnings results on Monday, which showed net profit after tax more than doubled to around $391million.  #ABCBusiness  Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Grandmother of Gus Lamont charged with unrelated firearms offences amid investigation | ABC NEWS
description: A 75-year-old has been arrested and charged with firearm offences following a search of the property in South Australia's north-east, where four-year-old Gus Lamont went missing last year. Police say the charges are not connected to the missing child. title: US ramps up pressure on Iran before nuclear talks | ABC NEWS
description: Iran's foreign minister is travelling to Geneva for the next round of nuclear talks with the United States, as tensions in the Middle East continue to simmer. The US maintains it's seeking a diplomatic solution, but continues to ramp up pressure on Tehran. title: Coles accused of deceptive discounts | The Business | ABC NEWS
description: Supermarket giant Coles has been accused of a "planned" campaign to mislead customers over price discounts.  The consumer watchdog, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC), is suing the supermarket giant in a lawsuit that a former ACCC boss has called "the case of the century". Coles denies the allegations and maintains its promotions are genuine.  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. description: Brett Pointing has been named as the interim Queensland police commissioner, replacing outgoing commissioner Steve Gollschewski who is retiring to spend more time with his family as he recovers from a cancer diagnosis.  #ABCNewsQld by Ciara Jones  Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE Read more here: https://www.abc.net.au/news/2026-02-16/brett-pointing-named-new-queensland-police-commissioner/106348482  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Destanee Aiava announces retirement, calls out 'racist' tennis culture | ABC NEWS
description: Australian tennis professional Destanee Aiava has announced her retirement from the sport in an explosive social media post.  The 25-year-old called out online trolls, while also claiming the sport had a "culture that's racist, misogynistic, homophobic and hostile to anyone who doesn't fit its mould".  Aiava last played at the Australian Open, where she was knocked out with Maddison Inglis in the first round of the women's doubles. title: Police say abduction of Sydney man a case of mistaken identity | ABC NEWS
description: Police continue to appeal for the safe release of an elderly Sydney man kidnapped in a case of mistaken identity. It is believed 85-year-old Chris Baghsarian was snatched just before daybreak from his North Ryde property. Detectives are investigating a disturbing video which has emerged, possibly showing Mr Baghsarian being assaulted by his captors. title: Fears Port Jackson sharks falling victim to SA algal bloom | ABC NEWS
description: Researchers investigating the apparent disappearance of Port Jackson sharks from Adelaide metro waters say they have failed to find a single egg from the recent breeding season. One ecologist says it is unclear whether the algal bloom has killed the entire local population, or simply driven them away. The Department of Environment and Water has spoken of repopulating areas decimated by the bloom, but it is not clear if that option is being considered for Port Jackson sharks. title: Fatal crash in western Sydney raises questions about police pursuits | ABC NEWS
description: Police policies on high-speed chases have been placed under scrutiny after two innocent women were killed in a collision with an allegedly stolen vehicle at Camden in western Sydney. NSW police officers say the crash occurred 40 minutes after they suspended their pursuit of the vehicle which subsequently caused the collision. title: Australian families linked to Islamic State fighters returning to Syria camp | The World | ABC NEWS
description: The ABC has been told Syrian authorities are not allowing a convoy of Australian families linked to Islamic State fighters to head to the capital Damascus, where they were going to plan their onward travel to Australia. It's believed there are 34 people in the group and the ABC has been told that Australian passports had been issued to them. Middle East Correspondent Matthew Doran reports. title: NT politician accused of bullying two female staffers, leaders stay silent | ABC NEWS
description: A member of the Northern Territory government has been accused of bullying by two female staffers, while heading up a prominent parliamentary committee late last year.  The formal complaints against the member for Fong Lim Tanzil Rahman allege he yelled and swore at the staffers.  The chief minister says the matter's been internally resolved, but won't provide any further detail. Matt Garrick has this report for ABC News Northern Territory. title: IOC defend selling 1936 Berlin Olympics t-shirts | ABC NEWS
description: The International Olympic Committee has defended its decision to sell merchandise commemorating the 1936 summer Olympics in Berlin, made famous after black American athlete Jesse Owens embarrassed German dictator Adolf Hitler by winning four gold medals.   Original reporting by Reuters.   Social version by David Douglas Stuart for the ABC News Social Media Team. title: Hillary Clinton says Trump position on Ukraine a 'historic error' | ABC NEWS
description: Hillary Clinton has spoken on the Trump administration’s position on Ukraine at a security conference in Munich.  The former US Secretary of State and presidential candidate said, "the effort that Putin and Trump are making to profit off the misery and death of the Ukrainian people is a historic error and corrupt".  Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky also spoke at the conference, calling for a 20-year security guarantee from the US before agreeing to any peace deal. title: Russia looks to developing countries to recruit new mercenaries | The World | ABC NEWS
description: As the war in Ukraine rages on, Russia is increasingly looking to the developing world to recruit new combatants. Recruits have come from Africa, Latin America and South East Asia, with allegations of systematic deception by Moscow sparking concerns from human rights advocates. Executive Director of Chasseur Group Munira Mustaffa spoke to The World's Girish Sawlani about the ethical implications of Moscow's recruitment efforts. title: Indonesia's marriage rates are falling | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Marriage rates in Indonesia have been declining for at least a decade, with online dating and the economic burden of marriage and parenthood a factor.  ABC Indonesia's digital journalist Natasya Salim told The World 's Girish Sawlani financial instability is one of the main reasons for the falling rate.
